alert.note: Alert for Eastern Foot Hills; Northern Foot Hills (South Dakota) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.senderName: NWS RapidCity (Western South Dakota and Northeastern Wyoming)
info.headline: Red Flag Warning issued September 07 at 1:38PM MDT until September 08 at 7:00PM MDT by NWS RapidCity
info.description: .Hot and very dry conditions will persist across northeastern WY and much of western SD this afternoon into this evening. Breezy winds will also continue across portions of northeastern WY, leading to critical fire weather conditions for the remainder of the afternoon into the evening. Late this evening into tonight, winds will decrease over the northeastern WY plains but increase over the northern and eastern foothills eastward onto the SD plains. These winds will limit overnight relative humidity recovery and likely lead to the development of critical fire weather conditions across the northern and eastern foothills late this evening through much of tomorrow. A trough crossing the area tomorrow will bring an abrupt shift to breezy northwesterly winds while relative humidity values remain low, leading to more widespread critical fire weather conditions across much of western and central SD into southern portions of northeastern WY from late tomorrow morning through the afternoon. ...RED FLAG WARNING IN EFFECT FROM 9 PM THIS EVENING TO 7 PM MDT THURSDAY FOR GUSTY WINDS AND LOW RELATIVE HUMIDITY FOR FIRE WEATHER ZONES 323 AND 324... The National Weather Service in Rapid City has issued a Red Flag Warning for gusty winds and low relative humidity, which is in effect from 9 PM this evening to 7 PM MDT Thursday. The Fire Weather Watch is no longer in effect. * AFFECTED AREA...Fire Weather Zones 323 Northern Foot Hills and 324 Eastern Foot Hills. * WINDS...West 10 to 20 mph with gusts up to 35 mph. * RELATIVE HUMIDITY...As low as 14 percent. * IMPACTS...The combination of gusty winds and low relative humidity would produce critical fire weather conditions.
info.instruction: A Red Flag Warning means that critical fire weather conditions are either occurring now, or will shortly. A combination of strong winds, low relative humidity, and warm temperatures can contribute to extreme fire behavior.

area.areaDesc: Eastern Foot Hills; Northern Foot Hills
